terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Spanish countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Spanish event. Rolling terrain with moderate access, moderate costs, and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Castellon Gravel Race is a regional event in Spain‚Äîrolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Spanish countryside is scenic and organization is solid, but the moderate access and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid Spanish rolling gravel race. Worth it for European riders. Not practical for most international riders.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Europe‚Äîyes, it's solid. If you're international‚Äîthere are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better value: regional gravel races. For similar Spanish terrain: Sea Otter Europe Gravel.

logistics.food: Castellon has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Spanish rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Jorge Padrones notes you arrive in Llucena to discover "big mountains around you as the only exit from the village" - rural isolation that limits infrastructure. The race sold out at 800 riders with 250 traveling from abroad, but basic travel details remain scarce for what's become "the most internationally popular gravel event so far in Spain."

length.explanation: The 97km distance let Alejandro Valverde average 28 km/h for a 3:27:53 finish, while Carolin Schiff rode solo for the entire second half to win in 4:20:08. Padrones confirms "the first flew at more than 25 km/h average" on this fast course that balances serious climbing with manageable distance. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Padrones describes "descending a gravel path at 65 km/h with some sharp corners" but clarifies "this was not a very technically demanding race" with no singletrack or rocky sections. The 72% gravel surface prioritizes speed over technical skills, creating what riders call "a fast course" through Spanish fire roads. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The 2,600m of climbing over 97km includes a 6.3km climb at 5.4% as the longest sustained ascent, plus the race-deciding final 1km at 10% gradient. Padrones acknowledges the climbing load as "a hard test" befitting a World Series event, but the varied gradients spread the suffering across multiple ascents rather than one monster climb. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 60¬∞F and lows of 41¬∞F, with a 23% chance of rain on any given day, and gusts reaching 32 mph. Padrones reports "temperatures around the 15 degrees Celsius along the race itself" with morning chill giving way to comfortable conditions. The February timing attracts international riders "encouraged... attracted by the mild weather we are used to having in the Mediterranean area at this time of the year." Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Starting and finishing in Llucena keeps you at Mediterranean coastal elevations despite the mountainous terrain. The 2,600m refers to elevation gain through climbing, not high-altitude racing conditions that would affect performance or require acclimatization. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Racing through every corner of Llucena's municipal territory on 72% gravel roads delivers proper exploration of Spanish mountain terrain most cyclists never see. The course design visiting the entire town area means discovering rural Spain, not just hammering a predetermined loop. February timing adds off-season adventure appeal when most European gravel racing shuts down.

prestige.explanation: Opening the 2026 UCI Gravel World Series globally and offering Worlds qualification elevates this second-year race significantly. Valverde's repeat victory and the international field of 800 riders builds credibility, but the event is still establishing its reputation against established European gravel races.

race_quality.explanation: The race-deciding final 1km climb at 10% gradient with its summit just 300m from the finish creates proper tactical racing, as seen when Valverde "used a final acceleration on the uphill finish" to drop competitors. Padrones praises "flawlessly organised" execution, though the event remains in its formative years.

experience.explanation: Padrones describes arriving to see "big mountains around you as the only exit from the village" before tackling 2,600m of climbing including fast 65 km/h descents with sharp corners. The mountainous Spanish terrain delivers what riders call "a hard test" worthy of World Series status.

community.explanation: Small-town Spanish racing has that authentic feel where the entire municipality of Llucena gets involved, with the course literally visiting every corner of town. It's too new to have deep community roots, but having Valverde show up for the inaugural edition suggests the local cycling culture takes it seriously. The intimate scale works in its favor.

field_depth.explanation: The 2025 elite fields included Carolin Schiff, Tiago Ferreira, Jan Bakelants, and 41-year-old UCI Gran Fondo World Champion Johnny Hoogerland alongside repeat winner Valverde. Top-25% finishers earn "the appreciated golden UCI medal" for Worlds qualification, attracting serious competitors to this 800-rider international field. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Worlds qualification opportunity through top-25% finishing, plus the post-race party with food and drinks, delivers strong value for what's become Spain's most internationally popular gravel event. The February Mediterranean weather and 2,600m of climbing provide serious racing at likely lower costs than peak-season European destinations.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs ‚Ç¨50-80. Llucena's rural mountain location limits accommodation options despite attracting 250 international riders who must navigate the logistics independently. February timing helps with seasonal pricing, but the limited infrastructure around this small Spanish village requires self-sufficient travel planning for visiting riders. Higher total cost than Badlands.

rider_intel.search_text: The Castellon Gravel Race features intense climbing with 3,000 meters of elevation gain in under 100K, described by riders as extremely challenging. The course profile consists primarily of climbing and descending sections. Riders recommend suspension forks despite the weight penalty, noting significant time savings on descents and improved confidence on technical terrain. Mountain bike cassettes are suggested for maximum gear range on this technical race. The challenging elevation profile makes this suitable for riders who love climbing but prepare for difficulty. Tire setup recommendations include 45mm width on front for grip with slightly narrower rear tires for reduced rolling resistance. The race is part of the UCI Gravel World Series.
